```
val snapshotDF1 = spark.read.format("org.apache.hudi")
      .load(basePath + "/202*/*/*/*")
```
other than these two I am good with this

> @nsivabalan - In the original post, if you take a look at the 3rd MOR screenshot, you will see that ID=2 shows up twice. If I am reading the read optimized table, should it only show ID=2 where __op is NULL since compaction hasn't been executed at that time? Why do I see ID=2 where __op = D in the read optimized table?

AWS support was able to reproduce this issue with EMR 5.31.0 and Hudi 0.6.0.

I also tried running the same script using Hudi 0.7.0, but experienced the same issue.

We are preparing production release and decided to use COW for now.

@n3nash : Addressed all your comments.

> > You only need to add tabproperties to the hive table metadata: spark.sql.sources.provider= hudi, you can automatically convert the hive table to the hudi table.
> 
> @teeyog can you please expand on this. is this related to this PR or a general comment?

If the hive metadata tabproperties contains ```spark.sql.sources.provider=hudi```, the parsing process of sparksql reading the hive table is as follows：
First step
[https://github.com/apache/spark/blob/62be2483d7d78e61fd2f77929cf41c76eff17869/sql/core/src/main/scala/org/apache/spark/sql/execution/datasources/DataSourceStrategy.scala#L302](https://github.com/apache/spark/blob/62be2483d7d78e61fd2f77929cf41c76eff17869/sql/core/src/main/scala/org/apache/spark/sql/execution/datasources/DataSourceStrategy.scala#L302)

Second step
[https://github.com/apache/spark/blob/62be2483d7d78e61fd2f77929cf41c76eff17869/sql/core/src/main/scala/org/apache/spark/sql/execution/datasources/DataSourceStrategy.scala#L261](https://github.com/apache/spark/blob/62be2483d7d78e61fd2f77929cf41c76eff17869/sql/core/src/main/scala/org/apache/spark/sql/execution/datasources/DataSourceStrategy.scala#L261)

The resolveRelation in the second step will go directly to the DefaultSource of hudi, so reading the hive table is automatically converted to reading the hudi table

> @teeyog if you could call FSUtils.getAllPartitionPaths() or add a new method `getNPartitionPaths()` and return the first N such partition paths using your traversal in the class `FileSystemBackedTableMetadata`

It has been modified to obtain the partition path by ```FSUtils.getAllPartitionPaths()```

I have created a JIRA to track this feature request: https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/HUDI-1595. It would require some level of intgeration within hudi to use the serde libraries provided by Glue schema registry, and use the appropriate deserializer to consume the record https://github.com/awslabs/aws-glue-schema-registry/blob/master/README.md. For now you have the option of using confluent schema registry.

I would also encourage you to open a feature request with AWS EMR team if you are trying to get this working on EMR. Helps us prioritize based on customer asks.

> I expected One new file with the 500kb file merged, but the clustering operation created more two files. Why? :)

Clustering is implemented using multi-version-concurrency protocol. This means we'll always create new files (to prevent concurrent readers from failing). Older files will be deleted by cleaner process based on configured policy. If you want just one file after clustering, please set "hoodie.clustering.plan.strategy.target.file.max.bytes" and "hoodie.parquet.max.file.size" to a larger value (2GB). 

> With this feature, the reader side needs to be changed too

Yes, clustering introduces a new type of commit called 'replacecommit'.  I dont know how athena is integrated with hudi. But, looks like athena needs to be upgraded to use hudi 0.7.  Temporarily, as a workaround, you could configure following cleaner policy "hoodie.cleaner.policy: KEEP_LATEST_FILE_VERSIONS" and "hoodie.cleaner.fileversions.retained: 1" to force cleaning older versions immediately.

@manijndl7 thanks for letting us know! no worries! hope to see you back soon

My thought: 
The released artifacts are official and verified, and should not be changed. The current problem does not affect users to obtain and run related artifacts from the Maven public repository.

If we need to fix an earlier issue like this, we should release some minor versions on the corresponding release branch. Similar to 0.x.1 or 0.x.2.

Doing a release for each of these versions is not a good use of time IMO. 

To be clear, I am not suggesting mutating the release (thats not a thing anyway). I was merely talking about adding the commit to older release branches. 

How about we just add a section on the README about `Building Older Releases` with this pom change? That way people who want to build releases can manually apply and build locally. Most of all, I would love to understand how other projects do it, before we make a call.

AFAIK, backport some fix to older release branches is very common in other project (eg: apache flink ). 
Adding a  section on the README may be a choice, but older release branches will not be buildable until the users notice the section and modify the pom.xml themselves. It may give some surprise to some users (eg: myself ). :)

> AFAIK, backport some fix to older release branches is very common in other project (eg: apache flink ).
> Adding a section on the README may be a choice, but older release branches will not be buildable until the users notice the section and modify the pom.xml themselves. It may give some surprise to some users (eg: myself ). :)

Yes, it's true in Flink. We can see that the release **branch** can still be evolved after some major branch release. While the minor release **tag** would be immutable.

I think it is still a problem in Hive2. In Hive2, Hive can not identify logical timestamp type.
Spark3 use hive2 lib, if we use spark sql with `enableHiveSupport()` to read a hive table, it may appear that spark read hive's field as timestamp type, and use hive2's parquet API to read timestamp. 
In Hive2 serd class, the type of timestamp must be `int96`, if we force parquet-avro to declare timestamp (TIMESTAMP_MICROS), this error will occur.

Folks, this is due to version mismatch between aws spark and apache spark.  Hudi releases are built against apache spark and aws typically follows up with a EMR release.  The problematic access is only on the MOR query, that explains why MOR is problematic, while COW is not.  https://dev.to/bytearray/using-your-own-apache-spark-hudi-versions-with-aws-emr-40a0 if interested on steps. 

If one of you could help verify, that the issue does not exist when querying from Apache Spark, we can route the issue accordingly. cc @umehrot2
